Subjective: The patient has been experiencing palpitations for several months.
The patient has been breathing rapidly for several months.
The symptoms have increased over the past two weeks.
The symptoms mainly occur at rest.
The patient has no chest pain.
The patient does not notice an irregular heartbeat
The patient does not experience dizziness.
The patient does not experience light-headedness.
The patient sometimes experiences shortness of breath when breathing rapidly.
The patient also experiences shortness of breath at work.
The patient has difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about work.
The patient sleeps an average of about 6 hours per night.
The patient works full-time (38 hours per week).
The patient regularly works longer days.
The patient asks whether there is a somatic cause for the symptoms.
The patient asks whether it would be useful to talk to a professional.
Objective: Auscultation of the heart reveals normal heart sounds.
No murmurs are audible on auscultation of the heart.
Heart rhythm is regular on auscultation of the heart.
Rhythm is equal on auscultation of the heart.
No abnormalities are heard on auscultation of the lungs.
Assessment: The symptoms are consistent with stress and tension.
The tension manifests itself in palpitations.
The tension manifests itself in rapid breathing.
The stress symptoms manifest themselves in sleep problems.
A somatic cause for the symptoms has not yet been completely ruled out.
Plan: Additional blood tests have been requested for Hb.
Additional blood tests have been requested for thyroid function.
Additional blood tests have been requested for liver function.
Additional blood tests have been requested for kidney function.
The patient will be referred to or will make an appointment with the POH-GGZ for guidance on stress-related symptoms.
The patient will receive lifestyle advice on incorporating active relaxation into their daily routine.
The patient will receive lifestyle advice on maintaining a daily structure and regularity.
The patient is advised to contact the occupational health and safety service for support with work-related stress.
If the symptoms increase, the patient is advised to return to the consultation hour.
If concerned, the patient is advised to return to the consultation hour.
